title: 104_hr2470
content: The Act is titled the "Second Amendment Reaffirmation Act of 1995" and includes findings. The "Second Amendment Reaffirmation Act of 1995" states that Congress lacks authority to require waiting periods or background checks for firearm sales, citing constitutional limitations and court rulings. Public Law 103-159 is found to violate the tenth and second amendments of the Constitution. The "Second Amendment Reaffirmation Act of 1995" argues against waiting periods and background checks for firearm sales, citing constitutional limitations and court rulings. Delays and erroneous denials for law-abiding citizens during emergencies like the 1992 Los Angeles riots are highlighted, along with concerns about potential abuse of background checks for gun owner registration. The Justice Department Task Force in 1989 highlighted the potential for automated tracking of individuals seeking to purchase firearms, regardless of legal prohibitions. SEC. 3. SECOND AMENDMENT RESTORATION. Public Law 103-159 and the Assault Weapon Manufacturing Strict Liability Act of 1990 are repealed, restoring any provisions of law amended or repealed by these acts. Amendments are made to sections of title 18, United States Code, regarding the delivery of records upon business discontinuance and firearm regulations. Amendments are made to section 924 of title 18, United States Code, allowing individuals to bring actions for damages related to civil or constitutional rights violations in connection with the lawful possession or use of firearms by the government. Section 926 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to prohibit the application of laws regulating pollutants to firearms and ammunition. Additionally, officers of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms are restricted from investigating individual firearm owners. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms requires approval for investigations exceeding $4,000. Cooperation with the IRS also needs approval. Violations can lead to imprisonment or fines. The names of firearms owners cannot be listed, recorded, or transferred without authorization. The Act prohibits the disclosure of firearms owners' identities to any government facility and prohibits the establishment of any registration system for firearms. Any records violating this Act must be destroyed within ninety days. Individuals can seek recourse for civil or constitutional rights violations by the government. The Act allows individuals to bring legal action for damages in federal court for violations of their rights by the government, with the possibility of receiving attorney's fees and costs if successful. SEC. 4. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is held invalid, it does not affect other valid provisions. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act takes effect immediately upon enactment.
